choices.text:
Sally has 3 brothers. Her brothers have 2 sisters. How many sisters does Sally have? Explain your answer
Sally's three brothers each have two sisters, so Sally has six sisters-in-law. However, the question is worded in such a way that it could also be interpreted as asking how many sisters Sally herself has. Since we don't know if she has any siblings other than her three brothers, there are several possible outcomes:

If Sally does not have any other siblings, then she would only have two sisters-in-law and no sisters of her own (since all of her brothers are married).
If Sally has one or more sisters who are unmarried, then she would have three sisters-in-law and at least one sister.
If Sally has one or more sisters who are married but not to the same two men as her brothers, then she could have any number of sisters-in-law (from zero upwards) and any number of sisters (from one upwards).
The question is ambiguous in that it does not specify whether Sally has siblings other than her three brothers. It also does not state which set of siblings the "two sisters" refers to, so there are multiple possible interpretations.
